qas.question: What are the proteins that organisms use to identify molecules associated with pathogens?
What are the antimicrobial peptides that are the main form of invertebrate systemic immunity called?
What cell type is also used for immune response in most types of invertebrate life?
What pathway that plays a role in immune response to viruses is present in all eukaryotes?
What proteins are used by very few organisms?
What are peptides that help microbes flourish called?
What is not used by any form of invertebrate?
What does not play a role in the immune response to viruses?

context: <a0_0><a0_1><a0_2><b4_0>Pattern recognition receptors<b4_0/><a0_2/><a0_1/><a0_0/> are proteins used by nearly all organisms to identify molecules associated with pathogens. Antimicrobial peptides called <a1_0><a1_1><a1_2><b5_0>defensins<b5_0/><a1_2/><a1_1/><a1_0/> are an evolutionarily conserved component of the innate immune response found in all animals and plants, and represent the main form of invertebrate systemic immunity. The complement system and <a2_0><a2_1><a2_2><b6_0>phagocytic<a2_1/> cells<b6_0/><a2_2/><a2_0/> are also used by most forms of invertebrate life. <b7_0>Ribonucleases<b7_0/> and the <a3_0><a3_1><a3_2>RNA interference<a3_1/> pathway<a3_2/><a3_0/> are conserved <b8_0>across all eukaryotes<b8_0/>, and are thought to play a role in the immune response to viruses.
